quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.text: Almost think of career as a product. So if you're building a good product, you think about, "Well, here's what a great product would look like," and then you break it into version one, version two, version three. Well, in some ways the reason I called my newsletter, my podcast The Skip is because I always think about not the next job, but the one after it.

quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.text: I'm actually really a big fan of a diverse set of experiences, that I think learning about pre-product market fit then seeing smoke turn into fire and witnessing and maybe shepherding that and then taking fire and turning it into something great and being an experience set where you can see the movie in these different frames makes you just a better builder.

quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.text: So many tech professionals are in these organizations with the expectation that they'll make money on their equity. And my sense is we're going to see lots of boards pulling back, companies essentially saying, "Hey, we're a scaled ocean liner, and now we need to go find product market fit." But doing that with 300 people and expectations of hitting a multi-billion dollar valuation just isn't going to happen.

quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.text: Think about the story, think about the skill, then solve your day to day, your week to week, your month to month, your performance review. That's my biggest advice. It's just like Amazon talks about building the press release before they start creating a product.

quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.text: You need someone to see the magic in you to be promoted. There is many of your listeners who have that magic but maybe have a manager or a promotion team who doesn't see said magic. And in that case, if you have the magic, you're in a bad setting and you just need to change. That could be a shift within the project. You could find a manager who sees it. It could be leaving the company.

quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.text: You have to be great at pulling feedback, listening to it. You have to triangulate it from people that don't see you all the time, that do see you all the time, your peers. But you have to create an environment of safety where people feel like there is no worry about retaliation or concern. And the more comfortable people are about giving feedback to you and the more you have the skills to pull it, the better shot you have of truly understanding what that real issue is and solving it.

quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.text: In a hundred years when the archeologists look back and they see tech in the early years of tech, they'll say that the biggest surprise was how much we thought it was okay to not train managers. The military probably didn't make that mistake for very long before they corrected it. If you're a good coder, you are ready to manage. That's the way the industry works. I think that there's such a loose coupling between the skills to be successful at building things and teaching people how to build.

quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.text: I think it's more like the sidecar on the motorcycle, where person's driving the motorcycle and I'm on the sidecar and whether I like it or not, I'm attached, but I have this relatively specific role of giving counsel. I think that that model of how do you share the steering wheel, not just say you got it or I got it or I got it for a while, and then I hand it to you is the key question.

quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.text: What I find is that you're more like the vampire knocking on the door of someone. You have to be invited in. You just can't walk through the threshold. And I think that no matter how senior the person that is the manager, you have to earn the right to be the person's manager.

quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.text: Everyone focuses on your superpowers, but no one ever thinks about what shadows they create. Great collaborators sometimes are very reticent to present their own opinions. People that are amazing at growth struggle to be innovative. People that are world-class storytellers struggle to get in the details. You're a structured thinker, but blue-sky innovations are very tough. You're an amazing listener, but you're very weak to be decisive.

quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.text: Ensure that the story you will tell about the work you're doing today is meaningful for your skip job. Use I in the sentence, do not use we. Master the story now. Understand the story. If the story sucks, you probably should be thinking through how to make the story not suck. I want that story to be incredibly compelling because whether you promote it or not, that story's compelling. You'll be promoted in career.

takeaways: Think of your career like a product: work backwards from your end state and always plan for the job after next, not just the next one.
The tech industry's failure to train managers is its biggest systemic weakness -- being a great builder does not make you a great manager, and management is a craft that must be learned separately.
Your superpowers create shadows that become your biggest blind spots at senior levels -- listen to contradictory feedback instead of dismissing it as anomalous.
Getting promoted requires advocacy, an available role, patience, and honest self-assessment -- most people who are stuck are blocked by one of these four factors, not lack of skill.
Build your career narrative intentionally: the story you tell about what you learned and accomplished matters more than collecting logos or titles.

contrarian_candidates.why: Calls out the entire tech industry for a fundamental failure to train managers -- argues that building skill and management skill are completely decoupled, contrary to the meritocratic assumption that top ICs make top managers
Argues managers must be invited in like a vampire -- you cannot just manage by organizational authority, which challenges the default assumption that a management title confers the right to manage
Reframes superpowers as liabilities at the executive level -- the very traits that made you successful create development blind spots that can plateau your career
